prompt: <description>Part 1: CAD model of a circular object with a central hole Creating the coordinate system Begin by creating a new coordinate system with the following parameters: * Euler Angles: [0.0, 0.0, -90.0] * Translation Vector: [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] Creating the 2D sketch on the XY-plane 1. Create a new 2D sketch on the XY-plane defined by the coordinate system. 2. Draw two circles in this sketch as follows: * Circle 1: Center at [0.375, 0.375] and Radius of 0.375, name it "circle\\_1". * Circle 2: Center at [0.375, 0.375] and Radius of 0.35, name it "circle\\_2". These circles define two loops, one for each circle. Loop 1 is formed by circle\\_1 and Loop 2 is formed by circle\\_2. Extruding the 2D sketch to generate the 3D model 1. Scale the sketch with a factor of 0.75. 2. Extrude the 2D sketch along the Z-axis, from 0 to 0.0125 units creating the final solid body using the "JoinFeatureOperation" boolean operation. Note that the extrusion direction is opposite to the normal direction. Part 2: CAD model of a circular object with a hollow center Creating the coordinate system Begin by creating a new coordinate system with the following parameters: * Euler Angles: [0.0, 0.0, -90.0] * Translation Vector: [0.025, 0.0, 0.025] Creating the 2D sketch on the XY-plane 1. Create a new 2D sketch on the XY-plane defined by the coordinate system. 2. Draw two circles in this sketch as follows: * Circle 1: Center at [0.35, 0.35] and Radius of 0.35, name it "circle\\_1". * Circle 2: Center at [0.35, 0.35] and Radius of 0.3438, name it "circle\\_2". These circles define two loops, one for each circle. Loop 1 is formed by circle\\_1 and Loop 2 is formed by circle\\_2. Extruding the 2D sketch to generate the 3D model 1. Scale the sketch with a factor of 0.7. 2. Extrude the 2D sketch along the Z-axis, from 0 to 0.075 units creating the final solid body using the "NewBodyFeatureOperation" boolean operation. This time, make sure the extrusion direction is in the normal direction. Final Shape Assembly The final shape is a metallic ring with a slightly tapered inner diameter. It is obtained by aligning Part 1 and Part 2 as follows: 1. Move Part 1 along the X-axis by 0.025 units. 2. Move Part 2 along the Y-axis by 0.025 units. 3. Position Part 2 such that it perfectly fits inside Part 1 to form the tapered inner diameter.</description>

Scale the sketch by a factor of 0.75. Transform the 2D sketch into a 3D sketch using the established coordinate system. On face_1, draw a rectangle with lines starting at [0.0, 0.0], [0.2857, 0.0], [0.2857, 0.2857], [0.0, 0.2857], and ending at [0.0, 0.0]. Transform the 2D sketch into a 3D sketch using the established coordinate system. Extrude the sketch to a depth of 0.1071 both towards and opposite the normal. **Part 3: Construct a three-dimensional rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom and a tapered middle section.** Create a new coordinate system with Euler angles of [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] and a translation vector of [0.0864, 0.015, 0.2143]. On face_1, draw a rectangle with lines starting at [0.0, 0.0], [0.2557, 0.0], [0.2557, 0.2557], [0.0, 0.2557], and ending at [0.0, 0.0]. Transform the 2D sketch into a 3D sketch using the established coordinate system. Extrude the sketch to a depth of 0.2143 in the opposite direction of the normal. The final shape should be a rectangular prism with a flat top and bottom, and a slightly angled front face, with vertical lines along its edges. The dimensions of the final shape are approximately 10 units in length, 5 units in width, and 3 units in height. Each intermediate part and the final shape will have a height of approximately 3 units, with different length and width values as specified for each part.</description>
